title: 110_hr5954
content: Presumptions of service connection for diseases associated with service in the armed forces and exposure to biological, chemical, or other toxic agents as part of Project 112 under laws administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. Presumptions of service connection for diseases associated with Project 112 under laws administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. This new section establishes a presumption of service connection for diagnosed diseases with increased incidence related to service, even without evidence during that period. The new section establishes a presumption of service connection for veterans who were subjected to chemical or biological warfare tests under Project 112 and develop a related disease within a specified period. The new section establishes a presumption of service connection for veterans exposed to biological, chemical, or other toxic agents associated with diseases, unless there is conclusive evidence to prove otherwise. The Secretary will determine when this presumption is warranted based on sound medical and scientific evidence. The Secretary will consider all medical and scientific information available when determining the association between exposure to biological, chemical, or other toxic agents and the occurrence of a diagnosed disease in humans or animals. The results must be statistically significant, replicable, and withstand peer review for consideration. The association between exposure to biological, chemical, or other toxic agents and the occurrence of a diagnosed disease in humans or animals is considered positive if credible evidence outweighs evidence against it. If the presumption of service connection for a disease is removed, veterans and survivors will still be entitled to compensation. The term 'Project 112' refers to the chemical and biological weapons program conducted by the Department of Defense from 1963 to 1973, including Project SHAD. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the chapter. Presumptions of service connection for illnesses associated with service in support of chemical or biological warfare tests or projects. Regulations, personnel records, and report concerning Project 112. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs within 180 days to notify veterans potentially exposed to biological or chemical agents during Project 112. The Secretary of Defense must transmit personnel records to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs within 30 days for those exposed. A report on Project 112, including costs and challenges, must be submitted to Congress within 1 year. The term "Project 112" refers to the chemical and biological weapons program conducted by the Department of Defense or other federal agencies from 1963 to 1973, including the Shipboard Hazard and Defense Project (Project SHAD). The document aims to document costs, benefits, and challenges of continuing the search for Project 112 participants, provide all known information about them, and address concerns from the Department of Veterans Affairs, veterans, and veterans service organizations.
